info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 22.

(1, 1).clue: The name of this Houston trio honors Texas bluesman Z.Z. Hill

(2, 1).clue: To North Americans, the sun reaches its vernal point in this month

(4, 1).clue: This presidential relative, quite logically, had his own brand of beer in the 1970s

(6, 1).clue: Forms of this atmospheric phenomenon include forked, streak & ball

(1, 2).clue: A road sign inspired the name of this band from the land "Down Under"

(2, 2).clue: If a business invests $10,000 in a product, when it has sold 100 of them at $100 each it has reached this point

(4, 2).clue: When this president was a governor, his brother Roger was arrested

(5, 2).clue: With so much brainpower on stage today, this "Living Dead" movie monster wouldn't know where to start

(6, 2).clue: This noun can precede chair, terrier or pudding

(1, 3).clue: Debbie Harry had often been called this, so it was "a natural" for the name of her band

(2, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew points to a flow chart on an easel pad.)  In a flow chart, a diamond shape represents this point of the process

(4, 3).clue: His wife had many brothers in the Confederate Army, prompting some to question her loyalty to the Union

(5, 3).clue: It was last call for this Scottish outlaw on Dec. 28, 1734

(6, 3).clue: From the Latin for "make similar", it's an exact duplicate

(1, 4).clue: This "Money For Nothing" group was named for its sorry financial condition

(2, 4).clue: After 4 hours of struggle & grit, we've reached this point for the first time, 6-3, 6-7, 4-6, 7-5, 5-4, 40-15

(4, 4).clue: His stepson by Dolley once owed debts of over $40,000 that the president himself had to pay

(5, 4).clue: Take a flying leap & name this type of reconnaissance plane or insect of the family Acrididae

(6, 4).clue: From the French for "to relate", it's one who tells stories & anecdotes with wit & skill

(1, 5).clue: The last name adopted by all members of this punk band was an alias used by Paul McCartney

(2, 5).clue: Author Malcolm Gladwell calls the moment when social phenomena reach critical mass this title point

(4, 5).clue: When he was veep, his brother Donald was involved in financial dealings with Howard Hughes

(5, 5).clue: G'day!  This wooden weapon can also be a scheme that does injury to its originator

(6, 5).clue: Italian poet who won 1959 Nobel Prize, or a Victor Hugo character

(1, 1).clue: According to this brand of frozen foods, "Nothing comes closer to home"

(2, 1).clue: 1980 miniseries that featured extensive Japanese dialogue (& Richard Chamberlain in a kimono)

(4, 1).clue: The long white leg hair is called feathers on this horse that originated in Lanarkshire, Scotland

(5, 1).clue: A version of this sculpture, one of your most famous works, was placed over your tomb in Meudon

(6, 1).clue: At one's post or work, & thus possibly not allowed to drink

(1, 2).clue: Like its other vitamins, this brand's Silver for adults 50 & over is "Always complete.  From A to zinc"

(2, 2).clue: Our head writer Gary Johnson still dreams about this "Queen of the Jungle" played by Irish McCalla

(4, 2).clue: This spotted breed developed by the Nez Perce was praised in Lewis & Clark's journal for its quality

(5, 2).clue: Rodin, you portrayed Paolo & Francesca, lovers in the Middle Ages, in this masterpiece seen here

(6, 2).clue: If you're having a winning streak in gambling, or maybe if you're a pat of butter, you're on a...

(1, 3).clue: This antibiotic ointment promises to help "minimize the appearance of scars while preventing infection"

(2, 3).clue: Don't know about you, but I'm waiting for this David Carradine series based on an Alan Ladd film to "come back"

(4, 3).clue: All the horses of this breed derive from 3 stallions imported into England between 1689 & 1728

(5, 3).clue: The controversy surrounding your monument to this French author was a real "human comedy"

(6, 3).clue: To be undecided or uncommitted is to be on this, maybe between 2 adjoining properties

(1, 4).clue: It's the brand of activewear & dancewear for women, whose logo is seen here

(2, 4).clue: This rock 'n' roll show that made Bobby Sherman a star premiered in September 1964, 4 months before "Hullabaloo"

(4, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from a horse corral.) These types of horses are bred for herding or running races of 1,320 feet

(5, 4).clue: The scenes on this monumental door were inspired by "The Divine Comedy", one of your favorite books

(6, 4).clue: It's what someone or something that's exceeded a normal life span is "living on"

(1, 5).clue: Lands' End still has its own catalog, even though it was purchased by this retailer in 2002

(2, 5).clue: Don Rickles exercised his "jaws" as this chief petty officer

(4, 5).clue: This is the breed used by the Spanish riding school in Vienna

(5, 5).clue: Rodin! Oh how you sculpted this princess, prior to her rescue by Perseus

(6, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a chalkboard diagram.)  A line that continues in its own direction, it's also part of this expression for where some people go when talking

(0, 0).clue: Born in 43 B.C., his most famous work begins, "My intention is to tell of bodies changed to different forms"
